body: 2 - Upcoming dividend:

body: # 2b - Optional full year top up (according to ZIM policy of "30-50% of the annual net income") of an additional 0-20% will range from:
[] $0.00 (as explained above) to ~20% of net income from Q1-Q3 + likely inaccurate generous consensus estimate of ~370million or ~$7.52
[] For a range of $0.92-$8.44 (based on high consensus).

created_at: but it has been beat down more than it should regardless. Way more bullish on DAC and GSL
column3: but ZIM still has a big upside to it in the longer term. But gleaning its intrinsic value is very difficult compared to lessor companies due to its current asset-light model and unsecured future revenue. Also what people seem to ignore is that it is using its huge cash position to earn interest. TTM non-operating interest income is $92 million
column4: which is close to annual operating incomes in the past on its own...

body: $ZIM Both the $30 price target and $15 price target set by analysts make sense if you look at it from their perspective.
ZIM probably will start to bleed money from next year due to their asset-light charter model
created_at: their income is dependent on charter rates+container shipping rates (fbx
column3: drewry etc etc)... Depending on how much ZIM bleeds cash in the future
column4: both $30 and $15 could be reasonable. But I'd think that $30 is more likely right now. $15 PT assumes that ZIM will keep chartering the same amount of ships at the same routes while rates keep falling to pre-covid levels. I think this assumption is extreme
column5: and I believe that ZIM management will stop chartering so many ships and shrink their fleet. Lots of renewals coming up
column6: with a gradual shift to LNG ships to decrease cost. ZIM is also prey to retail valuations according to only their dividend policy and not their retained earnings+ future earnings
